results.title: Bejart's Kabuki Ballet
results.creator_credit: Kiichiro Ito, Kanae Mayuzumi and Nihon Hoso Kyokai
results.brief_description: Traces the preparation for Marcel Bejart’s ballet production of “Chushingura” that was commissioned by the Tokyo Ballet in 1985 and saw a fusion between European ballet and Japanese Kabuki theatre. Choreographed by Bejart, the ballet was a simplification of a popular 9 hour Kabuki play based on a real incident in Japanese history of a group of 47 samurai who avenged the murder of their master and then committed ritual suicide. Bejart created harmony between the traditional Japanese theatrical form and European ballet through the incorporation of Kabuki gestures, movement techniques and props in the ballet’s choreography. Through the synthesis of dance and traditional Japanese costumes and the integration of Kabuki dance and theatre music into the orchestral composition that was to accompany the ballet. A ground breaking production for its unique combination of seemingly disparate performance cultures, “Chushingura” was the result of detailed research into the history of Kabuki theatre and dance and consultation with contemporary practitioners of the form. In footage of rehearsals and in interviews with Bejart and the Tokyo Ballet dancers, this process is discussed along with the themes that Bejart was exploring in the preparation for and final production of the ballet, complimented by mirrored sequences depicting a Kabuki performance of the popular tale and Bejart’s ballet. This documentary was also the Grand Prix Winner of the International Emmy Awards in 1986.

results.title: Being me
results.creator_credit: Keryn James, Susan Redden and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Being Me is an ABC health series for students in middle to upper primary school years, that “encourages kids to know themselves, like themselves and be themselves” (ABC). The eight twenty minute episodes are made in a style designed to engage children, with the use of vibrant colour and sound, numerous dramatisations, short comic skits featuring the superhero “Bounce Back Man”, recurring “Kid’s News” segments, and group discussions amongst school children. Presenter Alex Shepherd ties together and summarises the themes and strategies explored in each program. Episode 1 “Identity” looks at issues of individual identity, including how it is constructed and expressed; Episode 2 “Happy to Be Me” deals with self esteem. Episode 3 “Belonging” explores the dynamics of group affiliations and interactions; Episode 4 “Making Friends” investigates why and how we make friends; Episode 5 “Keeping Friends” examines how friendship is maintained in the face of everyday challenges such as arguments. Episode 6 “Power and Responsibility” delves into issues of responsibility and power in relationships, and examines the affects of bullying and other abuses of that power. Episode 7 “Changes” considers change as a normal and ongoing, if challenging, part of life; Episode 8 “Taking Risks” analyses how taking risks can be a necessary part of growing, and looks at how to assess and mitigate risks.

results.title: Being male
results.creator_credit: Don White, George Johnson, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: One effect of the women’s movement in western societies has been the gradual realization by some males that they are also trapped by stereotypes. In this film, sixteen- and seventeen-year-old boys talk candidly about how the traditional image of maleness fits their own experience. Young men, the film shows, are beginning to re-evaluate their role in society.

results.title: Behind the mosquito net = Dibalik kelambu
results.creator_credit: Teguh Karya, M Sukmajaya and Sukma Putra Film
results.brief_description: This film is one of a string of romantic melodramas involving three of the most influential people in the Indonesian film industry. Director Teguh Karya teamed Christine Hakim and Slamet Rahardjo (who were then both members of Teguh’s theatre group, ‘Teater Populer’) as husband and wife, Hasan and Lela. Hasan, unable to meet the expectations of his father-in-law whom the married couple is staying with, is fast losing his self-esteem. Forced to work as a taxi driver after losing his job, he develops an ambiguous relationship with another woman when the situation at home becomes intolerable. Winner of 6 Citra Awards at the 1983 FFI. Music by Eros Djarot, screenwriter Slamet Rahardjo. Cast includes Christine Hakim, Slamet Rahardjo and Nungky Kusumastuti. In Indonesion with English subtitles, which are sometimes difficult to read.

results.title: Beginnings
results.creator_credit: Clorinda Warny, Lina Gagnon, Suzanne Gervais, Gason Sarault and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film describes the animator’s personal view of the universe. Abstract landscapes evolve into strange, god-like figures whose images revert into landscapes. The movements are slow and dreamy. The product of an eclectic imagination, this universe draws on historical, literary, and classical sources to illustrate man’s close ties with nature. Awards: Eight including Ottawa; New York; Columbus; London; Los Angeles; Annecy.

results.title: Before we ruled the earth
results.creator_credit: Pier De Lespinois, Bill Latka, Discovery Channel and Evergreen Films
results.brief_description: Using dramatic historical re-enactments and computer animation this documentary provides a fascinating insight into the world of prehistoric life and the eventual evolution of the human race from primitive Homo ergaster to Homo erectus, from the rise of the Neanderthals and the Pleistocene era of the Cro-Magnons, to the advanced sophistication of the Paleo-Indians. We see how humans battle to survive alongside such prehistoric predatory beasts as the sabretooth cat, woolly mammoths and gigantic bears in often extreme conditions where it truly is the “survival of the fittest”. Episode 1. Hunt or be hunted: Begins in prehistoric Africa 1.7 million years ago with Homo ergaster and fast-forwards a million years to Homo erectus through to the Cro-Magnons. Discusses the evolutionary process and the importance of adapting to climatic and environmental changes, of developing skills to master the art of survival and of how the discovery of fire-making played such an important role in the evolution story. Episode 2. Mastering the beasts: Follows the Cro-Magnons to America revealing their tenacity in surviving harsh elements, extreme hunger and the company of woolly mammoths. Also focuses on the Paleo-Indians of North America as two small bands come together for a ritual buffalo kill. Based on available scientific evidence, this interpretive program is highly recommended as an educational tool. Narrated by John Slattery, story by Brian Fagan.

results.title: Before night falls [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Julian Schnabel, Jon Kilik and Grandview Pictures
results.brief_description: Before night falls is Julian Schnabel’s second feature, his follow-up to “Basquiat”. The story of Cuban poet and writer Reinaldo Arenas, the screenplay is based on Arenas’ memoirs. The film opens with Arenas’ idyllic, if impoverished youth - brought up by his adoring mother and a dictatorial father who forbade his son’s poetry. A shift to the city exposes Arenas to urban influences and his teachers encourage his artistic expression. Openly gay and politically active, the adult Arenas finds himself persecuted by the Castro regime and his writing is smuggled to France in order to be published. Javier Bardem plays Arenas as a passionate, talented hedonist whose attempts to escape incarceration are both daring and foolhardy. The cinematography depicts Cuba as a magical and beautiful place, saturated in decaying splendour, which is crippled by corruption and state sanctioned police brutality. Schnabel employs an episodic structure to relay the key moments of Arenas’ life. Cuba - a place teeming with culture, food, love, sex and passion - is contrasted with Arenas’ ‘freedom’ in New York. Despite his liberation Arenas is depressed, living austerely and the scenes take on a bleached aesthetic, reflecting perhaps the writer’s longing for his rich homeland.

results.title: Before It's Too Late - Teenage Suicide (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This important film can be used to teach students how to spot suicidal behaviour in their friends and it impresses upon them that they can actually save a life by being a supportive friend.

results.title: Bedknobs and broomsticks
results.brief_description: Angela Lansbury plays a prim and proper Eglantine Price, an amateur English witch who joins up with three cockney waifs to help save war-torn Britain from Nazi invaders. A film for all ages, Bedknobs and Broomsticks features ingenious animation, a hilarious soccer game where crocodiles, elephants, and other animals really kick up a storm. Brass beds fly, nightgowns dance, and airborne brooms sweep away young and old alike to a fun-filled world of fantasy.

results.title: Becoming a family
results.creator_credit: Martin Chilcott, Robert Page and Lifetime
results.brief_description: This program is about babies - having them, caring for them and watching them grow and develop. It is not only a comprehensive and practical guide to babycare but also shows what it is like to become a family and how people cope with the new relationships and feeling that a baby brings. It contains information on pregnancy, feeding, development, sleep, teething, cleanliness, safety and a host of other topics. It is designed especially to help you to enjoy the new life you have created by taking you into the lives and homes of new families who share their experiences (and babies) with you. The sections include: getting ready for a baby; pregnancy and birth (10min); the newborn baby - 0-6 weeks (32min); the settled baby - 6-12 weeks; the sociable baby - 3-6 months.
